page.title: 09CHANGING TIMES:FARMING
page.content: There are few farms but many crofts of varying sizes. The traditional methods of farming are still widely used although crofts now have new, modern machinery. This machinery may be co-operatively owned. In the past crofters did not make a profit. All the food and animals produced were used by the crofter and his family. The men usually went to the fishing in the summertime and so the women were left to work on the land. Today many crofts are worked part time with the crofter working elsewhere eg. Sumburgh Airport. The main crops grown have not changed over the years ie. potatoes, turnips, cabbage, barley and grass for hay. On the bigger farms they now make silage. The biggest farm in our area is Sumburgh Farm which once belonged to the Laird.
